papers.abstract: Interdisciplinary collaboration within digital humanities research requires brokering and boundary-crossing work. This article maps interdisciplinary exchanges between computer scientists, media scholars and information scientists to explicate how interdisciplinary brokering affects knowledge and tool production in the digital humanities. The analysis of qualitative data collected during a 17 month-long digital humanities research pilot - set to collaboratively test a digital Linked Open Data (LOD) search tool - provides insights into the exploratory search behaviour of a total of 122 (digital) humanities scholars, and how these insights informed brokering work within an interdisciplinary research team. The article argues that interdisciplinary collaboration first and foremost requires disciplinary recognition in order to succeed, and demonstrates how practical, empirical research insights - in this case about user research - mobilize interdisciplinary decision-making processes. Conclusions indicate in what ways computational tools and collaboration affect knowledge production, and suggest that understanding the stakes of digital humanities research with digital audio-visual sources requires an integrated perspective characterized by both theoretical interdisciplinary discussions and their empirical, practical application. The article furthermore concludes that digital humanities brokering and boundary work should not only revolve around tool development, but also requires self-reflexivity in aligning epistemological chasms between disciplines by means of collaborative translation practices.

events.Text: Interdisciplinary collaboration within digital humanities research requires brokering and boundary-crossing work. This article maps interdisciplinary exchanges between computer scientists, media scholars and information scientists to explicate how interdisciplinary brokering affects knowledge and tool production in the digital humanities.

Primary Object: interdisciplinary exchanges between computer scientists, media scholars and information scientists
Secondary Object: knowledge and tool production in the digital humanities

Context: Interdisciplinary collaboration within digital humanities research requires brokering and boundary-crossing work.
Purpose: to explicate how interdisciplinary brokering affects knowledge and tool production in the digital humanities

events.Text: The analysis of qualitative data collected during a 17 month-long digital humanities research pilot - set to collaboratively test a digital Linked Open Data (LOD) search tool - provides insights into the exploratory search behaviour of a total of 122 (digital) humanities scholars, and how these insights informed brokering work within an interdisciplinary research team.
events.Main Action: conducted a 17-month-long digital humanities research pilot to collate qualitative data

Agent: a group of digital humanities scholars worked cooperatively

Primary Object: collaboratively developed and tested a digital Linked Open Data (LOD) search tool
Secondary Object: researched exploratory search behaviors of participants

Context: A 17-month-long digital humanities research pilot was established to develop and test a digital LOD search tool.
Purpose: To explore and understand the exploratory search behavior of digital humanities scholars while collaborating on the development and testing of a digital LOD search tool.
Method: Data collection involved systematic observation and analysis of interactions between scholars and the digital LOD search tool over 17 months.
Results: Insights into the exploratory search behavior of scholars were gathered, revealing how their search patterns and strategies influenced the functionality of the digital LOD tool.
Analysis: These findings suggest that interactive features of the tool may enhance users' ability to navigate complex datasets effectively.
Challenge: One challenge identified was ensuring consistent participation rates across extended periods, potentially affecting data reliability.
Ethical: No explicit ethical issues were raised regarding data handling or participant contributions.
Implications: Such studies could provide valuable feedback for refining digital search tools tailored to academic disciplines.
Contradictions: There is no contradiction presented against existing literature cited.

events.Text: The article argues that interdisciplinary collaboration first and foremost requires disciplinary recognition in order to succeed, and demonstrates how practical, empirical research insights - in this case about user research - mobilize interdisciplinary decision-making processes.

Method: demonstrates how practical, empirical research insights - in this case about user research - mobilize interdisciplinary decision-making processes.

events.Text: Conclusions indicate in what ways computational tools and collaboration affect knowledge production, and suggest that understanding the stakes of digital humanities research with digital audio-visual sources requires an integrated perspective characterized by both theoretical interdisciplinary discussions and their empirical, practical application. The article furthermore concludes that digital humanities brokering and boundary work should not only revolve around tool development, but also requires self-reflexivity in aligning epistemological chasms between disciplines by means of collaborative translation practices.

papers.abstract: Digital literary studies constitutes a broad church. However, the field tends to divide into, at one pole, quantitative, macro-level studies of historical literary texts and, at the other pole, close-readings of individual born-digital literary works, typically hyper-avant-garde in conception. There is, in practice, little interplay between the two groupings. This article sketches a proposed “meso space” in between the two extant levels. Drawing on methods from book history, literary sociology, cultural studies, and digital media theory, this mid-level approach examines digital technology’s role in recasting the institutions of contemporary mainstream literature: the impact of powerful new digital intermediaries; the blurring of author/reader/reviewer roles; and the continued existence of print artefacts within online environments.

events.Text: Digital literary studies constitutes a broad church. However, the field tends to divide into, at one pole, quantitative, macro-level studies of historical literary texts and, at the other pole, close-readings of individual born-digital literary works, typically hyper-avant-garde in conception. There is, in practice, little interplay between the two groupings.

Primary Object: quantitative, macro-level studies of historical literary texts
Secondary Object: close-readings of individual born-digital literary works

Context: field tends to divide into two poles
Method: types of studies such as quantitative or qualitative
Results: little interplay between the two groupings
Analysis: tensions exist due to inherent differences
Challenge: limited success in integrating interdisciplinary work
Implications: narrow focus leads to fragmented understanding

events.Text: This article sketches a proposed 'meso space' in between the two extant levels. Drawing on methods from book history, literary sociology, cultural studies, and digital media theory, this mid-level approach examines digital technology’s role in recasting the institutions of contemporary mainstream literature: the impact of powerful new digital intermediaries; the blurring of author/reader/reviewer roles; and the continued existence of print artefacts within online environments.

Context: Using methods from book history, literary sociology, cultural studies, and digital media theory
Purpose: Reworking our understanding of the institutions of contemporary mainstream literature
Method: Employing a variety of methods and frameworks including book history, literary sociology, cultural studies, and digital media theory
Results: Impact of powerful new digital intermediaries
Continued existence of print artefacts within online environments
Analysis: Interpretation of other arguments presented in the abstract
Implications: Potential for future research on digital transformations in publishing sectors worldwide
